Masculine sg after the article: no mutation (y cariad).
Masculine sg after the article: no mutation (y map).
Masculine sg after the article: no mutation (y cydweithiwr).
Vowel-initial masc noun: article = ‘yr’; no mutation (yr enw).
Vowel-initial masc noun: article = ‘yr’; no mutation (yr oed).

Trigger: y (def. art., masc sg; ll-/rh exceptions)
Why: ll- not affected by SM; masc sg NIL (y llun).

Trigger: y (def. art., masc sg; rh exception)
Why: rh- not affected by SM; masc sg NIL (y rhiant).
Preposed adjective hen causes Soft Mutation (c→g), so ci→gi. Adjectives before the noun cause SM (except pob).
hen triggers SM (t→d): tŷ→dŷ.
prif before a noun causes SM (d→dd): diben→ddiben.
Preposed prif soft-mutates (b→f): bwriad→fwriad.
Set phrase shows the rule: prif causes SM and initial g disappears under SM → Weinidog.
prif causes SM (p→b): pwrpas→bwrpas.
Preposed adjective ‘holl’ causes Soft Mutation on the following noun (g→∅, p→b, t→d, etc.). Sogwaith → waith after yr holl.
‘holl’ before the noun triggers SM, so dillad → ddillad after yr holl.
holl before a noun causes SM (p→b): plant→blant.
ambell ‘occasional’ precedes and causes SM (t→d): tro→dro.
ambell triggers SM (c→g): cân→gân.
With SM, initial g disappears: gwall→wall after ambell.
unig before the noun causes SM (p→b): plentyn→blentyn (cf. unig blentyn ‘only child’).
Preposed unig soft-mutates (d→dd): dadl→ddadl.
Attached preposed modifier cyn- causes SM (ll→l): llywydd→lywydd (cyn-lywydd).
uwch- precedes and causes SM (c→g): capten→gapten (uwch-gapten).
is- as a preposed modifier causes SM; initial g disappears: golygydd→olygydd.
dirprwy used preposed causes SM (p→b): pennaeth→bennaeth.

After: yn y stryd wedi’i baentio’n wyn.
Why: Exception: pob always comes before the noun but does not soft-mutate it (no change here).
pob is the standard exception to the preposed-adjective SM rule; therefore no mutation.
After the subject, the first element of the complement soft-mutates: mynd→fynd. This is the core VSºO ‘subject-boundary’ rule in spoken Welsh.
Non-bod auxiliary + subject → VN soft-mutates (g→∅): gweld→weld, because there is no linking ‘yn’ to block it.
After the subject boundary the VN takes SM (d→dd): dod→ddod. Spoken rule, not a contact trigger.
Inflected gwneud as auxiliary + subject → SM on the VN: prynu→brynu.
After the subject e, the object starts the complement and soft-mutates (t→d): tŷ→dŷ.
The NP following the subject Aled is the first element of the complement, so it soft-mutates: car→gar.
Complement after the subject ‘i’ mutates: braw→fraw. Grammatical (subject-boundary) SM.
Object immediately after the subject y dyn gets SM (d→dd): darn→ddarn.
After the subject Heledd, the noun begins the complement and soft-mutates: copi→gopi.
First element after the subject y tîm takes SM (p→b): pwynt→bwynt.
Subject-boundary SM applies where possible; initials like ll are immutable, so no visible change.
rh is an immutable letter under SM, so there’s no change even after the subject boundary.
Non-bod auxiliary + subject → VN soft-mutates (t→d): torri→dorri.
Northern ‘(d)daru’ as auxiliary: after the subject the VN takes SM: cyrraedd→gyrraedd.
Inflected ‘dylai’ + subject → VN soft-mutates (d→dd): dysgu→ddysgu.
Modal-type verb ‘Hoffwn’ with subject → following VN gets SM: prynu→brynu.
After the subject, the VN loses g- under SM: gwybod→wybod. This is grammatical SM, not contact.
Inflected gwneud + subject → VN soft-mutates (c→g): colli→golli; other mutations in the clause don’t block this grammatical SM.

After: y rhestr, os gwelwch yn dda?
Why: Inflected cael (Ga i) + subject → VN soft-mutates: gweld→weld.
Noun immediately after the subject e begins the complement, so it soft-mutates: cynnig→gynnig.
With bod as auxiliary, the linking yn blocks the subject-boundary SM on a VN, so mynd stays radical.
In periphrastic tenses with bod, ‘yn’ must be present and cancels the otherwise expected post-subject SM on a VN.
After the subject ni the first complement word soft-mutates (p→b): papur→bapur. Particle mi doesn’t change the rule.
Non-bod auxiliary + subject → VN takes SM (d→dd): darllen→ddarllen.

After: Freddie i’r parti, bydda i’n dweud wrtho.
Why: Use os for a real/likely ‘if’. Put a normal future/present verb after it (here daw). Os itself doesn’t cause soft mutation.

After: hi’n dod heno, awn ni draw.
Why: Os introduces a likely condition; follow with an ordinary future like bydd. No mutation from os.
After os, use the normal form (oes ‘there is/are’ in if-clauses). Os doesn’t mutate the next word.

After: chi gipolwg, rhowch wybod i ni.
Why: Real ‘if’: os + ordinary future cewch. No soft mutation from os.
Use os with a normal future form (caiff ‘will get’). Os is not a mutation trigger.

After: hi ar y trên, bydd hi yno’n brydlon.
Why: Likely ‘if’: os + future (aiff ‘will go’). No mutation after os.
Set phrase type: os + gwelwch (‘if you see’). The g stays—os doesn’t soften it.

After: chi’n gynnar, cawn ni ddechrau’n brydlon.
Why: Os takes an ordinary finite verb (ewch ‘you’ll go/come’); it doesn’t mutate.
Natural Welsh: os + simple future/imperative-like form (arhoswch). Os itself causes no SM.

After: chi’n gofyn, cawn ni ateb clir.
Why: With a real condition use os and a normal future (byddwch). No mutation from os.
Negative if-clause: os na + ordinary future (bydd). Os still doesn’t mutate.

After: ni seibiant, parhawn ni i weithio.
Why: Another real ‘if’: os + cawn (‘we’ll get’). Os is not listed among SM triggers.
Use pe for imaginary/unreal situations: pe bai… ‘if… were’. Pe chooses conditional forms; it doesn’t mutate.

After: i’n cael saib, baswn i’n dod.
Why: Pe bawn i… ‘if I were…’. Unreal/hypothetical; pe itself is not a mutation trigger.

After: i yn dy le di, fyddwn i ddim yn gwneud hynny.
Why: Spoken/written pe tawn i (= petawn i). Same unreal meaning; no mutation from pe.
Plural conditional after pe: pe bydden nhw…. Pe marks unreality; it doesn’t mutate the verb.

After: hi’n dod yn gynnar, byddai’n well.
Why: Pe + conditional (byddai). Choose pe for hypotheticals; no soft mutation involved.
Colloquial tasai fo… = pe bai e…. Tasai is already the verb ‘to be’; it doesn’t mutate the next word (clywed stays radical).
Colloquial taswn i… = pe bawn i…. Again, no mutation on the following word (gwybod).

After: yn gynnar, âsem ni ar unwaith.
Why: Spoken tase/tasai are common (= pe bai). They don’t mutate the next word (dod unchanged).

After: mwy o amser, bydden ni’n gorffen heddiw.
Why: Plural colloquial tasen ni… matches pe bydden ni…. No mutation of the following word (cael).

After: dim ots gen ti, arhoswn ni ychydig.
Why: Negative unreal: pe na bai… ‘if … were not’. Pe signals unreality; it doesn’t trigger SM.
Another closed negative: pe na fyddai…. Focus is the conditional form; no mutation from pe/na.
With other verbs, pe still just marks unreality: pe gallai… ‘if … could’. No mutation from pe.

After: ni dalu, byddai popeth yn iawn.
Why: Pe + conditional plural (gallen ni ‘we could’) is common; pe doesn’t soften the verb.
With ei (her) before a vowel-initial noun, add h- at the start: ei hysgol hi ‘her school’. This is standard; many speakers drop it in speech.
ein + vowel-initial noun takes h- in the standard language: ein henw ni ‘our name’.
Do NOT add h- after eich in the standard language: eich enw chi (not eich henw).
eu + vowel-initial noun takes h-: eu harian nhw ‘their money’.
ei (her) adds h- before a vowel-initial noun: ei hoedran hi ‘her age’.
ein + vowel-initial noun → h-: ein hamser ni.
eu + vowel-initial noun → h-: eu henwau nhw ‘their names’.
No h- after eich: eich ysgol chi (standard).
ei (her) + vowel-initial noun → h-: ei haddysg hi ‘her education’.
ei (her) causes Aspirate Mutation on c/p/t (c→ch): car→char. No h- because the word starts with a consonant.
ei (her) aspirates t→th: tŷ→thŷ.
ei (her) aspirates p→ph: papur→phapur.
ei (his) gives Soft Mutation on consonants, but with a vowel-initial noun there’s no change—and no h-: ei enw e.
With compound prepositions the second element takes a possessive; 3sgf can add h- before a vowel: ar ei hôl hi ‘after her’.
ein before a vowel-initial second element can add h-: wrth ein hymyl ni ‘beside us’.
With ei (her) before a vowel-initial noun, add h- at the start: ei hysgol hi ‘her school’. This is standard; many speakers drop it in speech.
ein + vowel-initial noun takes h- in the standard language: ein henw ni ‘our name’.
Do NOT add h- after eich in the standard language: eich enw chi (not eich henw).
eu + vowel-initial noun takes h-: eu harian nhw ‘their money’.
ei (her) adds h- before a vowel-initial noun: ei hoedran hi ‘her age’.
ein + vowel-initial noun → h-: ein hamser ni.
eu + vowel-initial noun → h-: eu henwau nhw ‘their names’.
No h- after eich: eich ysgol chi (standard).
ei (her) + vowel-initial noun → h-: ei haddysg hi ‘her education’.
ei (her) causes Aspirate Mutation on c/p/t (c→ch): car→char. No h- because the word starts with a consonant.
ei (her) aspirates t→th: tŷ→thŷ.
ei (her) aspirates p→ph: papur→phapur.
ei (his) gives Soft Mutation on consonants, but with a vowel-initial noun there’s no change—and no h-: ei enw e.
With compound prepositions the second element takes a possessive; 3sgf can add h- before a vowel: ar ei hôl hi ‘after her’.
ein before a vowel-initial second element can add h-: wrth ein hymyl ni ‘beside us’.
Nos + day-name means 'on [day] night'. After nos the day soft-mutates where possible: m→f, so Mawrth→Fawrth. This is a listed contact trigger and is shown in examples.
After nos the day takes SM where possible (m→f): Mawrth→Fawrth. High-frequency pattern for naming nights.
Nos triggers Soft Mutation on the day name; m→f gives Mercher→Fercher.
Use nos + day for 'on [day] night'; SM applies where possible: Mercher→Fercher (m→f).
After nos, g- drops under SM, so Gwener→Wener.
Contact SM after nos: g→∅, hence Gwener→Wener.
Nos causes SM on the day name; ll→l, so Llun→Lun. Attested usage 'Nos Lun'.
With nos + day, apply SM where possible: Llun→Lun (ll→l). See examples of 'Nos Lun'.
Nos still introduces the time phrase, but Iau is vowel-initial so there’s no visible change under SM.

Before: Mae'n dawelach yn y dref Nos
Why: Vowel-initial day name: SM cannot show on a vowel, so Iau stays Iau after nos.

After: am naw yn gyfleus i ti?
Why: Example pattern 'Nos Sadwrn…'; initial s has no soft-mutation, so form is unchanged.
Nos + day phrase; s- does not mutate under SM, so Sadwrn remains Sadwrn.
Sul begins with s, which has no soft-mutation; nos marks the time but the form stays Sul.
Time phrase with nos; s- is immutable for SM, so Sul does not change.
